text: grilling ribs is typically an all-day
affair but with brine boiling you can do
it the whole thing in under an hour
start with your ribs and cut them in
half for this you can do up to three
racks at a time I'm using spare ribs but
you could of course use st. louis-style
or baby back they all work perfectly
well in this technique and what I love
about brian boiling is it takes the
guesswork out of it and often times it's
hard to get the meat tender to the bone
but still juicy and flavorful throughout
with regular brining you soak the meat
in cold water usually overnight to
impart flavor but here we're combining
the brining and cooking whole head of
garlic just put the whole weight of your
body onto it to smash the clothes and we
can keep the skin and all that's pretty
much all the work to do the water and
the grill does the rest for the brine
boiling have six quarts of water to a
boil in a large stockpot and to that a
cup of granulated sugar and a cup of
coarse salt now this may sound like a
lot but it really does take all of this
I promise you this will really make the
meat nice and flavorful in that head of
garlic that we crushed skin and all give
it a quick stir to insure that the sugar
and salt have dissolved before adding
the ribs in these go now believe it or
not you could also do this technique
with beef short ribs or whole chicken
legs pork ribs like this will need to
boil for 30 minutes to become tender at
the bone for whole chicken legs you will
only need to boil for 20 minutes and if
you're doing beef ribs 40 minutes and
set a timer for 30 minutes and you'll
want to start preheating your grill as
well our ribs have been boiling away for
30 minutes and it's nice and tender at
this point you could let the meat cool
to room temperature and then refrigerate
it for up to a day and then just pull it
back out of the fridge before grilling
so it's got that great make-ahead
component as well if you are going right
onto the grill just let the meat dry out
for a few minutes before you see
using them and carry on and you can see
how the meat has pulled away from the
bones and that's another indication that
it's a nice and tender salt and pepper
generously the seasoning on the surface
of the meat will also help us to build a
crust when we're on the grill lots and
lots of freshly ground black pepper and
our good friend olive oil a drizzle over
the meat now if you like to use a dry
rub you could certainly do that here
instead of the salt and pepper if you're
on an outdoor grill prep the coals for a
direct heat cooking I'm using a stovetop
grill so I'm over a medium-high flame
and we'll probably have to do these in
two batches since these ribs are already
fully cooked and tender at the bone all
we're really doing here is getting them
nice and charred on the outside with a
crust to develop even more flavor and
that wonderful texture that you get from
grilling so this takes about five to ten
minutes okay let's take a peek yeah very
nice okay so we're starting to get some
char and I'm just going to keep grilling
and turning these occasionally until
we've got that nice golden brown color
all over and then we can baste we've
built a nice crust on our ribs and now
we can do our basting this looks so
delicious and smells amazing a little
bit on both sides and give it a turn the
barbecue sauce will caramelize when it
hits that grill and you really only need
to do this in the last minute or two of
grilling a good slather on this side if
you're using it now these are so
flavorful from the brine boiling that
really the barbecue sauce is just bonus
flavor they're perfectly delicious just
as they are without any kind of sauce or
rub and then a quick flip on the other
side one more little base oh yeah okay
and there you have it grilled pork ribs
on a weeknight in under an hour
believe it happy eating
you
